												INTRODUCTION:Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II Chaos Rising, is the first expansion pack to the Dawn of War II RTS game by Relic Entertainment. Although it uses the basic principles laid out by Dawn of War II, it adds new and interesting mechanics to the formula which makes this expansion unique in itself.The player takes the role of the 'Force Commander' from the original Dawn of War II along with his band of Space Marines. Here, one year after the Tyranid Invasion, the  capital planet of Aurelia, long lost in the Warp, has once again emerged. It is now up to the Blood Ravens to find out what vile things it has brought from the depths of the Chaos infested Warp.PROS:+ Old Formula with new Mechanics: - The expansion adds a 'Corruption' bar that measures how much your characters and soldiers are tainted by Chaos. The player will now have to be more careful on their actions since certain events carry consequences that may drastically alter the story.+ Carry Over Progress: - Rarely do I encounter a game that will allow a carry over of your save files with all (most) of your progress. Lucky for us, Chaos Rising is one such game.+ Fun new Toys: - Extended Skill Tree, New Wargear, new Squad Member(s), some new Maps (also a CON, see below), and an extended story to the Lore of the Blood Ravens will keep the players entertained as they develop new tactics and builds for their Space Marines.+ Squadmates Does not Die as easily: - This is just an observation on my part but it seems that the Squadmates of your Sergeants doesn’t die as often as they did on the original game. This is a huge bonus FOR ME, since I thought it was kinda 'wrong' that Space Marines died way to easily back in Dawn of War II.CONS:- Shameless Map Recycling: - Most of the maps from the original Dawn of War II game were heavily reused in this expansion where the devs just rotated the default camera angle 90 degrees and tried to pass  them off as new maps.- Uneven Voice / Sound Levels: - The OST was great as was the Voice Acting, but the speech sound levels were not properly leveled. Some voices play very loudly which hurts the ears, others play softly that it is drowned by the background music.- Too Short: - I found the campaign to short with fewer missions than the original game. Optional quest are a rarity which limits the possible enjoyment of Space Marine builds.- Heretics: - Filthy Chaos worshiping Heretics.CONCLUSION:GOOD EXPANSION, I like this expansion and enjoyed playing its campaign. It has expanded the lore that surrounds the Blood Ravens Chapter by adding more mystery and intrigue to an already secretive Space Marine Chapter. The new Corruption Mechanic as well as the multitude of new Wargears and expanded skill tree shall keep the players entertained with new build possibilities and tactics.It may be worth the full price for some people but seeing how short the Campaign was, I would rather have people buy it during a Sale. This is still a great game and should be bought at some point by people who liked the original Dawn of War II game.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? 												Chaos Rising is the first expansion to Dawn of War II(Please note: Chaos Rising can be played via Dow2, so in reality I have played more than 0.1 hours of this game)Dawn of War II: Chaos Rising takes what Dow2 did well and expanded it. Letting your allies die, failing to stop an invasion, and murdering your own people cause your troops to become corrupted. Become too corrupted, and you fall to Chaos, abandoning your former battle-brothers and embracing demonic power. You can also reduce corruption by helping out around the sector, but demon powers are cooler :)Multiplayer is basically the same, but with Chaos as a playabel faction. Overall, a very solid expansion. If you enjoyed Dow2, I would recommend the sequel.

												Warhammer 40K Dawn of War 2 Chaos Rising is the standalone expansion to Dawn of War 2 and it shows in quite a lot of ways that THQ is not only capable of taking criticism, they can take that criticism and turn it into game fixes and improvements.Perhaps most notably and most importantly, the single-player campaign. No longer will you be fighting the same battles on the same maps over and over again. Now every single map is a unique entity, properly designed filled with story and gameplay triggers. Although this does mean the campaign is a good deal shorter than in Dawn of War 2 the trade-off is well worth it. Instead of getting only a couple of good missions and a ton of generic ones you now only get good quality missions. This also makes the storyline more condensed as you no longer have 5 generic missions in between every revelation and it keeps your interest up much more efficiently.The campaign meta-game continues to use the RPG elements from Dawn of War but introduces a new one, corruption. As you play through the game you will find corrupted artifacts and face gameplay choices that result in your heroes slowly turning towards Chaos if you give in to temptation. Although this mechanic is not fully realized, you can't join the forces of chaos, it does give you some interesting choices along the way and a fairly significant storyline consequence towards the end of the game.Perhaps the most immediate impact of the corrupt mechanic is the various abilities your heroes can unlock as they give in the dark influences. Although many of the abilities feel like just filler a few of them are actually powerful enough that you might opt for corrupting one of your men just to grasp that power. The corrupted weapons work much the same way, some of them being immensely superior to their regular counterparts.In terms of multi-player the situation is much as the same as in the main game, nothing has really changed except for the addition of a couple of new heroes in Last Stand. GFWL is still present as are the heavy duty matchmaking and connection issues.Graphically and sound-wise nothing has really changed either, the game still maintains a high quality in both albeit some of that might come from my infatuation with the general art and sound style of the WH40K universe.When it comes right down to it Chaos Rising is an expansion that improves significantly upon the main game and has taken several steps to correct mistakes made in the original. Although it is an expansion that focuses mostly on the single-player aspects of the game it still manages to feel like a total revival and come out looking superior in every way.

												There are many major changes in Chaos Rising coming from Dawn of War II which include newer gameplay mechanics and more varied mission map templates. Expect tougher and more cunning foes that requires better strategies and tactics to defeat. There's are new characters and a new enemy race to contend with. A new Corruption/Redemption system takes the stage towards Blood Ravens combat level advancement where the maximum level is increased to 30 from 20. The Strike Cruiser Armageddon is destroyed but the newer vessel, Retribution, will take you to view planets from its Bridge. Your squads may have special interests on certain missions. The unit customization has been improved upon, new skills and new Unique wargear written in Green, Blue, or Pink text are now added to the game. Wargear drops are random and dependent on your current level. GFWL has been removed and the game is now integrated into steam works. This game has lots of replay value - campaign, coop, last stand, multiplayer modes. I would highly recommend this game to everyone, the game is still fun in late 2014 as it was in 2010 when it was first released!

												I have absolutely loved the Warhammer 40,000 series - I own almost all the games. The original Warhammer and Medieval: Total War are what pushed me down the deep rabbit hole of strategy games.If you like intense, action-packed squad-based strategy games, then you will absolutely love this game. Warhammer (and Total War) are easily 2 of the granddaddies of real-time strategy. I have to admit, however, that I do prefer the original Warhammer more than the sequel because that one was not entirely squad-based - it was an RTS with building management like the Age of Empires series and Rise of Nations (make buildings to train units). In this game, you do not build any structures, you only need to worry about controlling your squad members. The aesthetics are spectacular - lots of special effects and carnage. I love that your equipment is extremely varied and actually looks different when you change it with new loot you've acquired. The music and sounds are great and appropriate for the gritty theatre of war found in the Warhammer 40,000 universe. The controls are not too difficult to pick up, however, if you want to be efficient then you need to become comfortable using hotkeys to maximize your micro-ing ability (you will need to rapidly use skills against your enemies and items to buff/heal you). The learning curve is moderate to difficult - you will have an advantage if you are familiar with RTS-games and/or the Warhammer franchise. If you are new, the tutorial mission is very good - and actually pretty fun even if you already know how to play.The Warhammer 40,000 universe is massive, with so much lore coming from the books (much like Star Wars {before it all got retconned =( }), and the story is very good - it continues after your actions from the previous games (including expansions). Your characters level up throughout the game, and you can invest these points into different skills, unlocking abilities and perks at particular intervals. You can also outfit them with whatever (applicable) items you may find in your adventures. If you have lots of junk items, you can also trade them for experience, which is great for helping you level up faster. During gameplay, you will do a lot of micromanaging to keep your squad alive. You will also utilize cover, flanking, and many of the skills (ex: anti-personnel grenades, warcry offensive buff) to help you survive each level. If you enjoy squad-based strategy games that offer a good challenge, give this game a try. You may also come to enjoy the expansions.Definitely recommend.

												Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II Chaos Rising is a real-time strategy / tactical role-playing video game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by THQ for Microsoft Windows based on the fictional Warhammer 40,000 universe. It is the sequel to the Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War video game series.  Dawn of War II features a non-linear interplanetary campaign, as the Space Marines. The campaign can be played either as single-player or cooperatively with another player through an online connection.The game's campaign departs from those of its predecessors in several key features. One of the most notable departures is that there are no base-building elements, unlike in previous Dawn of War titles. Instead, the player chooses the units to be used prior to beginning a mission, cannot build new units once the mission begins, and has only limited reinforcement options. Has serveral multiplayer modes of play.  Adds Chaos Marine, Elves, and Tyranid avatars.Chaos Rising is set one year after the events of Dawn of War II and the defeat of the Tyranid invasion (as well as the Eldar and Ork forces) of sub-sector Aurelia. The campaign marks the return of the Blood Raven heroes from the previous game, the Chaos Lord Eliphas from Dark Crusade, Derosa as the new governor of Meridian, and the heretical Vandis.New to Dawn of War II: Chaos Rising is the Corruption System. In the campaign there are often multiple objectives which will complete a mission; depending on which one a player chooses to complete, they will become more or less corrupted.for more info:

												An excellent expansion to an excellent game. The campign picks up the story where the first ended, and this time it's chaos forces you are up against with your Blood Ravens squad.There is an excellent corruption mechanism that really makes you fight chaos's corruption on a personal level - there are various sideobjectives that you can choose to do for usually a big item reward, for example choose to destroy the statue of a space marine hero. It also comes with corruption points, and those will slowly but surely take away your soul: your corrupting heroes and his fellow squad members will slowly lose their abilities (your saves carry over from vanilla DoW2 by the way!) and gather new demonic ones instead, along with their looks (chaos items have a corruption level requirement) and even their personality in conversations. Other side activities that are sometimes difficult, also come with corruption points - such as defending a temple the chaos forces want to destroy, and at the same time you are on a time limited objective in the other corner of the map. May you fail to defend the temple, your corruption level increases, so you are really fighting to stay pure and also constantly tempted by the power chaos offers. Because of this, there are 6 different ending to the campign that vary based on your corruption level, and the story can slightly change depending on which squad member of yours is the most pushed to the dark side.The campign is way more linear, the endlessly generated sidemissions are also gone, the open maps are gone and you are usually given one or two way of approach, though your tactics with the added corruption changes add another layer to the already big pool of tactical and character build options. There is a new "support mage" type of hero joining you, the buffing fireball throwing Jorah. Personally I didn't like him at all, but it's always nice to have additional characters.For multiplayer, you obviously get a new faction in the form of Chaos. Existing factions also got new units (free for all players who own DoW2 only and not this expansion), and obviously new maps with a new chaos hero for Last Stand.WHAT TO BUY CHAOS RISING FOR?If you liked vanilla Dawn of War II's campign, this is a fantastic campign expansion for it definitly worth even full price. The corruption mechanism that lingers above every mission, every man, really makes you personally fight the temping chaos that offers great power, but costs yourself.WHAT NOT TO BUY CHAOS RISING FOR?Multiplayer and Last Stand. The game's multiplayer is entirely played in the last expansion, Retribution, and because vanilla DoW2 and Chaos Rising used Games for Windows Live ( it got removed years after relase, don't worry it's full steamworks title now, just like Retribution ), the multiplayer players are separated from each other (DoW+CR and Retri are the 2 groups). Also Retribution includes everything for multiplayer, including it's new faction, and Chaos aswell without the need to own Chaos Rising.

												Dawn of War II had a very mixed reception. Many wanted to keep the base-building elements of 1, even though they did not fit the 40K world at all. On the other hand, 1 became so perfect with the expansions and the patches that II was definitely a culture shock. The game is split sharply in two, with an isometric, squad-based action RPG in single player and a fast-paced RTS chess in multiplayer.Of those two personalities, the campaign was the weaker. The missions resembled one another much too much and posed very little challenge. Enemy squads could be taken out piecemeal before a slow, slow boss battle. The storyline and the Space Marine characters were interesting, however, and Chaos Rising completely fulfilled the promise of it's predecessor. In single player, all the squads level up as you play, and since there are many more possibilities than resources in the skill trees, it pays to plan forward. You also get loot drops during and after missions, and choosing who uses what requires forethought as well. The actual combat is very intense indeed, with wave after wave breaking themselves on the Emperor's Chosen. You get to retry missions and keep the loot and XP, which is possibly too forgiving, but at least some missions have a turn deadline after which they fail. The campaign also has an interesting Corruption mechanic. The best gear is corrupted by Chaos, and using them or making certain other choices will take your heroes toward power and damnation, with boons and setbacks along the way. The lore side of things is well-studied as always. If you find a powerful Heavy Bolter (a super-deadly machine gun, if you will), for example, it comes with a little lore blurb detailing how this master-crafted artifact ended the lives of hundreds of heretics and was then blessed by the priests of Terra. It is possible that lore professors are not happy but that is in their nature. The rest of us, whether it be ordinary 40K fans like me, or friends of good games in general, will enjoy Chaos Rising. Retribution perfected the multiplayer but those interested in a great single player experience should start here.

												I rate the game Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Chaos Rising 3/5. OK.If you want more of the same campaign with the same characters as the original Dawn of War II game you should definitely give this add-on a try. However, there really isn't a lot else to this game except it lets you play as Chaos forces in the multiplayer modes and has multiple endings.The single player campaign is nifty in that you can easily pick up your characters and their various customized skills and many of their items pretty much where the main campaign of Dawn of War 2 left off. On the downside though the final boss fight of this add-on's final mission is needlessly frustrating and very poorly designed. On the easiest difficulty, playing it twice I must admit I was unable to beat the game's final boss. The ending mission's boss fight is a LOT harder than any of the boss fights leading up to it (those I had absolutely no trouble with but fighting against Ulkair himself is ludicrously frustrating).Perhaps the signle best thing about this game is how the single player campaign also has several endings and which ending you get seems to depend heavily on how you did and what choices you made in most of the previous missions of the add-on leading right through to the ending. These endings range from your main character being executed to you and your squad being proclaimed heroes (an excellent variety of endings). These multiple endings and the manner in which you must arrive at them (through the decisions you make over the course of the entire add-on) are a very welcome change from how most games tend to work, and the manner in which this game executes its multiple-ending structure well done even when compared to many other games which do have multiple endings. Getting one ending versus another in Chaos Rising is not so simple or easy as deciding between flipping one switch after the final boss fight versus another (as was true in Deus Es: Human Revolution). in Chaos Rising, which ending you get depends on what objectives you fulfill or not and what items you choose to use and not all along the way, almost from beginning to end.Although the multiple-ending structure adds some potential replayability to this game, although the game itself, its story and which missions you have access to and what order they are arranged in is, for the most part, arranged in a fairly linear fashion and the frustrating final boss fight serves as a bit too much of a counterweight to this game's various strengths. Also, there are still no single-player campaigns which let you play as any force other than that of the Blood Ravens Space Marines from the original Dawn of War 2 and endings in the Warhammer 40K universe can be predictable due to the sheer implacability of the game's setting. Regardless of what you do, war is going to continue (and so sequels are going to happen) but this is true to the franchise.

												Summary: A definite blast to play through, and worthy follow-up to Dawn of War II- for the most part. Note: This review focuses on the single-player campaign.The Good: There's a fair bit to praise.-The addition of new weapons and more character options for the character's strike team is a definite plus, at least initially.-The addition of Chaos as an enemy faction and the implementation of the Corruption mechanic are welcome additions, with worthwhile bonuses at the completely Pure and Corrupted stages, and wargear that reward either the Pure or Corrupt. The missions tie into this as well- Pure objectives take some effort to achieve, while Corrupt objectives are easy for the careless (or callous) player to accidentally (or deliberately) complete.-Those who have played Dark Crusade will recognize an old friend from that game, and while his new voice is a debatable change, he is very much the same smug, scheming character.-The boss fights throughout the game are suitably epic (as befits 40k), and the atmosphere of being in a galaxy that can never seem to stay safe is also there (as also befits 40k).-Furthermore, most of everything else that DoW II did well is still present here- very competent meshing of RPG and RTS styles with a deep statistics and upgrade system, complented with an extensive range of wargear.-The game generally performs well- the only problems I experienced with it were frame rate hitches when multiple large explosions occurred at once.-Lore. LOTS of it. Knowledge is power, so feel free to empower yourselves.The Bad: The game's definitely not perfect.-Balancing remains an issue- for instance, once the player acquires enough suits of Terminator armor to outfit everyone who can wear it, there generally isn't a reason to use regular power armor, relegating a fair number of late-game wargear choices to either just looking nice in the armory (for the sentimental, like myself), or being donated for experience.-Chaos Rising is still just an expansion- the story is shorter and more directed than it was in DoWII, and there are fewer missions. The objectives from DoWII that originally boosted some wargear options (i.e. the Signum, Rosarius and Relay Beacon) are now just mission objectives and experience boosters. The removal of defense missions definitely reduces the impression that your strike force is stretched thin across the sector and as such the feeling of tension suffers a bit.-The only campaign available is still the Space Marine campaign- while I liked it, those wanting to play as someone else will be disappointed.-The resolution of the Corruption storyline struggles to keep all of its threads consistently tied. Some of the villains' actions don't make a huge amount of sense over the course of the game, compared to others. A mixed bag, as far as this aspect goes.The Debatable: For better or for worse...-The game is still a DoWII-style game. It's more an RPG/RTS hybrid than a full-on RTS. There is no base-building or economy management. Everything focuses on the units you bring with you at the start. I didn't mind, but those wanting an RTS experience like Dawn of War 1 won't find it here.-Corruption and Purity. Unless the player is completely Pure or very Corrupt, the bonuses they get are near-worthless. This way, the game is only tense if the player wishes to stay Pure, as diving headlong into Corruption is easy if the player doesn't find staying Pure worth the trouble. There's no bonus for trying to find a balance, and the tension is lop-sided. That said, it may be the point of the whole exercise, so your mileage may vary.-Steve Blum is EVERYWHERE in this game. Take that for what you will.To wrap up: It's good. Not perfect, but still really good. I'd recommend playing on a higher difficulty (Captain for the average player, Primarch otherwise), and trying to stay Pure. The two lower difficulty levels make staying Pure way too easy and sap the tension out of the game. But, if you're just here to see the plot without wanting your favorite Space Marines fall to the dark influences of Chaos, then Sergeant or Initiate are fine, you spineless abhuman.

Posted: April 16, 2016
												Dawn of War II was a nice surprise. Breaking away from the regular mold of RTS games to create something more action oriented was a bold move that paid off. The campaign had a lot of hectic moments and offered some interesting RPG elements to help build a sense of progression throughout it's missions.Chaos Rising takes that RPG-lite system a step further and introduces some branching paths to the games various missions. Doing certain objectives (or failing to do them) may "corrupt" your squad, which can unlock more Chaos oriented abilities. You also have the reverse, which is Redemption points. It brings a further level of depth to how you can tackle missions, as well as introducing slight alterations to the story based on your choices.The story is also dramatically improved over what the base game had. It deals with the uprising of the Chaos Space Marines and how one of your own may be a traitor. While you can't directly fail a mission, some of the scenarios are out of your control, in terms of victory. You fight unending odds and need to retreat, which ramps up the tension quite a bit.It all ends with a twist that you shape based on your choices, but it's never directly stated how that works. It makes for a far more realistic take on the morality systems usually in place of RPG systems. Losing one of your finest squadmates to Chaos can be a devastating blow and knowing you could have prevented it makes it more agonizing.As far as the general gameplay goes, there aren't really any new additions (aside from Corruption/Redemption). Everything functions the same and you still can collect gear to improve your squads. You have a new Hero in the form of The Librarian. He acts has a healer and a ranged caster, which can help tremendously in the more closed off environments in the campaign.There are some missions reminiscent of the atmosphere that the Alien films made famous. You will be traversing through derelict vessels looking for Bio-samples and other materials. Ambushes are frequent and your squad is often outnumbered, so a strong emphasis is put on tactical manuevers more so than brute force.The campaign is about half the length of the main game, which is a plus and a negative. While the main game became a bit repetitive towards the end, Chaos Rising seems to teter between being excellent and being bland. While the Corruption/Redemption mechanic does allow for different approaches to certain objectives, they almost always culminate in a boss battle.The general difficulty is also much higher than the main game. It makes for certain missions that feel a bit cheap, as you often just don't have the manpower to overcome the odds. Since you can't build units on the fly, you're often forced to retreat and wait for reinforcements. It makes some missions take upwards of 30 minutes to complete, which just drags out the pacing.Overall, I think the campaign is better, but it does have more problems. It's not a bad attempt at expanding the groundwork set in Dawn of War II, but more could have been done to keep the consistency of quality at a high level. Still, more of the same would have been sufficient, so I admire Relic for attempting to mix things up.As I said in my review for the base game, the multiplayer is practically non-existent. I believe that is more down to the second expansion, Retribution, being the first Dawn of War II title on Steamworks. Chaos Rising and the base game were added to Steamworks only 2 years ago, but that was 3 years after Retribution released.While I couldn't find any games for co-op or competitive, the functionality is present. That means the co-op campaign is an option for people who want to bring a friend along. It would probably mitigate some of the difficulty concerns I had, but it would also be cool to tinker with the morality system with a buddy.Regardless, I would call this expansion unessential. It isn't bad, but it's mostly for the more hardcore of fans. Dawn of War II provides basically everything this game has, save for the Chaos Space Marines. If you really want, you could just get Retribution, which includes a campaign for every race.You could do much worse, though.7.5/10
